title: 112_hr3351
content: The Act titled "Franchise Education for Veterans Act" allows the use of educational assistance for franchise training. The GI Bill now includes various training programs for individuals not on active duty, such as apprenticeship, on-job training, cooperative programs, and training at approved establishments for franchises. The GI Bill now covers training programs at approved establishments for franchises, with limitations on the amount of educational assistance payable for such programs. The GI Bill covers fees for training, a housing stipend based on E-5 pay grade, and a stipend for educational costs. The maximum amount payable is $15,000. The GI Bill covers training fees, housing stipend based on E-5 pay grade, and educational costs up to $15,000. The number of months of entitlement for training is determined by dividing the total educational assistance paid by the full-time monthly institutional rate. Payment cannot exceed the individual's available entitlement. The GI Bill provides educational assistance to veterans, with adjustments made based on entitlement criteria. A veteran cannot receive more than 12 months or $15,000 in educational assistance under this program. Amendments have been made to the Post-9/11 GI Bill regarding approved programs. Amendments to the Post-9/11 GI Bill include adding franchise training options and expanding approved programs to include specific training programs. The Post-9/11 GI Bill amendments now allow for franchise training options and expanded approved programs, including specific training programs with housing stipends. The Post-9/11 GI Bill now includes a monthly stipend for books and supplies during training. The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides a monthly stipend for books, supplies, equipment, and other educational costs up to $15,000. Veterans entitled to educational assistance receive amounts based on specific clauses and percentages. The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides educational assistance up to $15,000, with limitations on the duration and total amount of assistance a veteran can receive. Payments are made for pursuing a program of education or training. The Post-9/11 GI Bill provides educational assistance for pursuing a program of education or training at a specified establishment, with payments made upon certification of enrollment by the Secretary.
